## Florida Hires Tulane Coach Jon Sumrall as Head Football Coach - <small>`apnews`</small>

- [source](https://apnews.com/article/florida-jon-sumrall-tulane-6e845f60d9f2144ef52171a722f80569)
- _Published: 2025-11-30 16:36:30+00:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `college football, coaching changes, University of Florida, Jon Sumrall, Tulane Green Wave, Lane Kiffin, Scott Stricklin, Dave Caldwell, AP Top 25, Group of Five, Southeastern Conference, rebuilding, salary cap, transfer portal, NIL payments`</small>

### Summary

Florida University has hired Tulane head coach Jon Sumrall as its new head football coach, selecting him after Lane Kiffin reportedly chose LSU. Sumrall, a 43-year-old former linebacker at Kentucky and head coach with two consecutive Sun Belt championships, signed a six-year, $44.7 million contract averaging $7.45 million annually. The move comes amid fan criticism of Athletic Director Scott Stricklin, who faced backlash for not landing Kiffin, and reflects a broader trend of recruiting from Group of Five conferences to rebuild in the competitive Southeastern Conference. Sumrall is expected to bring in an NFL-style general manager, Dave Caldwell, who has Super Bowl and AFC title game experience, to manage salary cap and transfer portal demands. The Gators, currently 4-8, are hoping Sumrall can restore success, especially after the firing of Billy Napier, who was criticized for poor performance and missteps. Sumrall’s rapid success at non-Power Five programs and his track record of reaching conference title games make him a notable hire, though it may be seen as a consolation prize by some fans.

### Key Takeaways
  - Florida hired Tulane coach Jon Sumrall as its new head coach, selecting him as a second-choice after Lane Kiffin reportedly chose LSU.
  - Sumrall signed a six-year, $44.7 million contract with incentives, averaging $7.45 million annually.
  - Sumrall has a strong track record: 19-7 in two seasons at Tulane, winning consecutive Sun Belt championships and reaching the American Conference title game twice.
  - The Gators are seeking to rebuild under Sumrall, who is seen as a potential 'Urban Meyer 2.0' to restore success in the powerhouse Southeastern Conference.
  - Florida's previous head coach, Billy Napier, was fired in mid-October after a 22-23 record over four seasons, leading to fan dissatisfaction and public criticism of Athletic Director Scott Stricklin.
  - Stricklin faced backlash from fans, including a rally and a website titled FireScottStricklin.com, but retained support from the Board of Trustees, which approved his coaching search.
  - The hiring reflects a shift toward hiring from Group of Five conferences and a move to rebuild Florida’s football program with new leadership and structures.
  - Sumrall will remain with Tulane through the American Conference title game and potentially the College Football Playoff if Tulane qualifies.
  - Florida is also preparing to hire Dave Caldwell as general manager, who previously won a Super Bowl with the Philadelphia Eagles and built a successful roster with the Jacksonville Jaguars.
  - The Gators have a 4-8 record, showing a need for immediate improvement, and are expected to bring in outside coordinators and an NFL-style GM to manage salary cap and transfer portal demands.

### Named Entities

    - Head coach hired by the University of Florida
    - Sumrall is the central figure in the article, representing Florida’s new direction in football leadership with a proven track record of success in non-Power Five conferences.

    - University of Florida's college football team
    - The Gators are the primary team undergoing a coaching change, reflecting broader trends in college football realignment and program revitalization.

    - College football team from Tulane University
    - Sumrall’s prior success with the Green Wave demonstrates his coaching effectiveness at non-Power Five schools, making him a viable candidate for Florida’s rebuild.

    - Former head coach who reportedly declined the Florida job
    - Kiffin’s decision to go to LSU instead of Florida illustrates competitive dynamics among top college football hires and the influence of regional and financial factors.
- **Scott Stricklin**
    - Athletic Director of the University of Florida
    - Stricklin made the hiring decision despite fan backlash, highlighting the tension between administrative leadership and public expectations in college athletics.

    - General manager hired by Florida
    - Caldwell brings NFL experience and roster-building expertise to help Florida manage salary cap and talent evaluation amid the transfer portal boom.

    - Caldwell’s Super Bowl win with the Philadelphia Eagles adds credibility to his ability to manage high-performance rosters in college football.

## Death toll in Hong Kong apartment complex fire hits 146 - <small>`aljazeera`</small>

- [source](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/11/30/death-toll-in-hong-kong-apartment-complex-fire-hits-146)
- _Published: 2025-11-30 11:31:50+00:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `Hong Kong, fire tragedy, construction safety, public protest, government oversight, corruption investigation, disaster response, residential fire, community mourning, safety audit`</small>

### Summary

A massive fire in Hong Kong’s Wang Fuk Court apartment complex, which burned seven of eight high-rise buildings over two days, has killed 146 people—the highest death toll in Hong Kong in over 75 years. The fire, fueled by flammable bamboo scaffolding and foam boards during renovations, spread rapidly and left 100 people unaccounted for and 79 injured. Authorities found 18 more bodies, bringing the total to 146, and continue a three to four week search. Public anger grew over repeated warnings about unsafe construction, leading to a petition with over 10,000 signatures calling for an independent investigation and corruption review. As a result, the government suspended 28 construction projects by Prestige Construction and Engineering Company, and at least 11 people, including three company officials, have been arrested. Over 4,600 residents are displaced and now housed in emergency shelters, with widespread grief and calls for justice and systemic reform echoing across the community.

### Key Takeaways
  - The fire in the Wang Fuk Court apartment complex in Hong Kong resulted in 146 fatalities, marking the deadliest fire in the city in over 75 years.
  - The blaze originated from flammable materials—bamboo scaffolding and foam boards—used during renovation work, which rapidly spread the fire across seven of the eight buildings.
  - A total of 100 people remain unaccounted for, and 79 were injured, with ongoing efforts to locate and identify victims.
  - Residents had previously raised concerns about unsafe construction practices and repeated warnings about fire hazards, highlighting a failure in oversight and communication.
  - The Hong Kong government suspended 28 construction projects by Prestige Construction and Engineering Company for safety audits following the disaster.
  - At least 11 people, including three company officials, have been arrested in connection with the fire and related activities, including a petition demanding an independent investigation into possible corruption.
  - A public petition launched by a group, including Miles Kwan, gathered over 10,000 signatures before being closed, reflecting widespread public anger and demand for accountability.
  - Over 4,600 residents were displaced and are currently housed in emergency shelters or city hotels, with authorities working on long-term housing solutions.
  - Public mourning and demonstrations occurred, with over 1,000 people gathering to pay tribute, expressing grief and demanding justice and systemic reform.

### Named Entities
- **Wang Fuk Court**
    - An eight-apartment residential complex in Hong Kong where the deadly fire occurred.
    - The site of the fire that caused 146 deaths, the central setting of the tragedy and the focus of the investigation and public mourning.
- **Hong Kong**
    - A special administrative region of China where the fire and its aftermath took place.
    - The location where the disaster occurred, affecting public safety, governance, and social trust in construction oversight.
- **Shuk-yin Tsang**
    - Head of the Hong Kong Police Casualty Unit, who provided updates on victim counts and search progress.
    - A key official providing authoritative data on the death toll and unaccounted individuals during the investigation.
- **Cheng Ka-chun**
    - Officer in charge of the Police Victim Identification Unit, who reported on body recoveries and search status.
    - A central figure in the identification and search process, emphasizing uncertainty and ongoing risks.
- **Miles Kwan**
    - 24-year-old individual arrested in connection with a petition calling for an independent probe into construction safety and corruption.
    - A symbolic figure representing public demands for transparency and accountability in government and construction oversight.
- **Prestige Construction and Engineering Company**
    - The contractor responsible for renovations in the Wang Fuk Court complex.
    - The company under investigation for unsafe construction practices and responsible for the suspension of 28 building projects after the fire.
- **Joey Yeung**
    - 28-year-old resident whose grandmother’s apartment burned in the fire.
    - A personal voice reflecting public grief and demand for justice from the victims' families.
- **Jeffery Chan**
    - A civil servant who visited the site to pay respects.
    - A representative of public sentiment, expressing emotional impact and the need for community support.
- **Bamboo scaffolding and flammable foam boards**
    - Materials used during renovation that ignited and spread the fire.
    - Direct cause of the fire’s rapid spread and a key factor in the tragedy’s severity.
- **Petition for independent probe**
    - An online petition launched by a group demanding a review of construction oversight and corruption.
    - Reflects public outrage and systemic distrust in construction safety and governance.

### Important Dates
  - **2025-11-30**
    - The date of the news article's publication, indicating the most recent update on the ongoing investigation and aftermath of the fire.
  - **2025-11-30**
    - The date when authorities provided the latest update on the death toll and ongoing search efforts.
  - **2025-11-30**
    - The day the police held a news conference and updated the public on the number of victims and unaccounted individuals.
  - **2025-11-30**
    - The day that public mourning and protests over the fire were observed, with over 1,000 people gathering to pay tribute.
  - **2025-11-30**
    - The day that the government announced the suspension of 28 building projects by Prestige Construction and Engineering Company for safety audits.

### Important Timeframes
  - **From _2025-11-28_ to _2025-11-30_**
    - The two-day period during which the fire burned through seven residential buildings in the Wang Fuk Court estate, resulting in the highest death toll in Hong Kong in over 75 years.
  - **From _2025-11-28_ to _2025-11-30_**

## Locking in: How people are embracing winter arc without burning out - <small>`bbc`</small>

- [source](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cm2w79447vvo)
- _Published: 2025-11-30 00:03:07.024+00:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `culture, meme, social media, motivation, mental health, work ethic, gaming, fitness, student life, language trends, burnout prevention`</small>

### Summary

The article explores the rising cultural phenomenon of 'locking in' — a phrase used to describe committing to focused, intense effort despite short-term discomfort for long-term gains. It traces the phrase's roots in African American urban culture and its recent surge in popularity via social media and motivational content. Personal stories from students, gamers, and fitness professionals illustrate how 'locking in' is used to maintain discipline in academic, professional, and creative pursuits, often inspired by narratives from TV and anime. While the phrase is effective for motivation, the article cautions against burnout, emphasizing the importance of balance, variety, and peer support. Despite being widely used, 'locking in' did not make the 2025 word of the year lists, underscoring its cultural resonance over linguistic formality.

### Key Takeaways
  - The phrase 'locking in' is being used to describe a commitment to focus and persistence through short-term discomfort for long-term benefits, such as fitness, productivity, or personal development.
  - The concept draws inspiration from media narratives like TV shows and anime, particularly 'villain arcs' or transformative journeys, which help individuals feel a sense of purpose and motivation.
  - The phrase has roots in African American urban culture, with early references dating back to 2009 on Urban Dictionary, but gained widespread popularity in 2024–2025 through motivational content and internet memes.
  - While the phrase is used positively to encourage discipline, there is a risk of burnout if taken too seriously; experts recommend balancing effort with rest and variety.
  - Social support and accountability (e.g., workout partners, peer groups) are highlighted as effective tools to maintain motivation without exhaustion.
  - The phrase is now widely used in a light-hearted, communal way among university students and online communities, suggesting it has evolved from motivational slang to a shared cultural expression.

## Hong Kong fire: Death toll rises to 146 as thousands pay their respects - <small>`bbc`</small>

- [source](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cp34yk7z6yxo)
- _Published: 2025-11-30 12:13:41.891+00:00_
- **Society & Culture**
- <small>tags: `Hong Kong, fire, Wang Fuk Court, death toll, construction safety, corruption investigation, national mourning, public grief, firefighting, international response, scaffolding safety, emergency response, civil society, independent inquiry, historical fires`</small>

### Summary

A devastating fire at the Wang Fuk Court housing complex in Hong Kong's Tai Po district killed at least 146 people, making it the deadliest fire in the region in over 70 years. The blaze spread rapidly across seven of eight tower blocks, fueled by flammable materials like plastic netting and bamboo scaffolding, and was exacerbated by failed fire alarms. As the death toll continues to rise with 150 people still missing, authorities have launched investigations into possible negligence and corruption in construction and renovation work. Eight people have been arrested on corruption charges, three on manslaughter charges, and the government has suspended construction on 30 private projects. A three-day national mourning period was observed, with thousands gathering to pay respects, demonstrating deep public sorrow and solidarity. The incident has reignited debates over construction safety practices, especially the use of flammable scaffolding, and sparked civic activism, including a petition for an independent inquiry. The fire has also prompted emotional international responses, with Indonesian and Filipino consulates confirming national losses.

### Key Takeaways
  - At least 146 people have died in the Hong Kong fire, which is the deadliest in over 70 years.
  - The fire started in the Wang Fuk Court housing complex in Tai Po and spread rapidly across seven of eight tower blocks due to flammable materials such as plastic netting and bamboo scaffolding.
  - The death toll continues to rise, with 150 people still missing and 79 injured, indicating ongoing recovery and identification efforts.
  - There are widespread accusations that flammable construction materials and negligence in maintenance or fire safety contributed to the spread of the fire.
  - Eight people have been arrested on corruption charges related to renovations, and three on manslaughter charges, with ICAC alleging gross negligence by those in charge of the construction company.
  - The fire reached peak temperatures of 500C (932F), and 12 firefighters were injured, highlighting the extreme danger and severity of the incident.
  - All fire alarms in the eight blocks failed to activate effectively, leading to residents being unaware of the fire’s onset.
  - Thousands of people have gathered at the site to pay respects, with queues stretching up to 2km, showing strong community solidarity and grief.
  - Indonesia's and the Philippines' consulates confirmed deaths among their nationals, underscoring the international impact of the tragedy.
  - Hong Kong's Buildings Department has suspended construction work on 30 private projects as a precaution.
  - A 24-year-old man was detained on suspicion of sedition for participating in a petition for an independent inquiry into the fire.
